Issues.Title: ngClass from component method restores original classes
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Description I'm using Bootstrap tabs and ngClass to append additional classes. I found that when using a component method for ngClass that it seems the original classes are getting restored when a component within the tab container changes. This does not happen when using an object directly within ngClass or by using [class.] syntax. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-bypyy7 Notice that the 'active' class gets restored in the first example in the project, but not the others. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

# üöÄ feature request
Directive routerLinkActive knows when a link is active. Based on that, add "aria-selected=true" attribute to the component.

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/router


### Description
Directive routerLinkActive knows when a link is active. Based on that, add "aria-selected=true" attribute to the component.


### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
RouterLinkActive already takes `routerLinkActiveOptions` as input. We can extend that to support this new feature.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
Alternative is to define my own directive based on routerLinkActive, which I may do in the mean time. But I see this as a core accessibility improvement which should be supported natively.

Issues.Title: refactor(core): run migration schematics for v8 beta and rc releases
Issues.Body:
Currently the `static-query` and `template-var-assignment` schematic only runs
for `8.0.0` which does not include any betas or release candidates. We want to
run the schematic in the beta's and RC in order to get early feedback about the
schematics. Enabling it promptly with V8 stable release can result in accidental
breakages that we would like to fix/identify before.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(core): run migration schematics for v8 beta and rc releases" (#29735)

Issues.Title: No way to set global options on HttpClient ( { observe: 'response' } )
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/.... HttpClient / HttpInterceptor ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... There doesn't seem to be a way to set global options for an HttpClient. The only close option I see is configuring an HttpInterceptor and set the options within each request. `const req = _request.clone();` It doesn't look like the update object is aware of the HttpClient options such as **{ observe: 'response }** ``` clone(update: { headers?: HttpHeaders; reportProgress?: boolean; params?: HttpParams; responseType?: 'arraybuffer' | 'blob' | 'json' | 'text'; withCredentials?: boolean; body?: T | null; method?: string; url?: string; setHeaders?: { [name: string]: string | string[]; }; setParams?: { [param: string]: string; }; }): HttpRequest; ``` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/... ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**
**Anything else relevant?** I'm not clear if there is some other way to handle this as my use case is to simply get the Http Response Code from the response. Of course, I can configure the **{ observe: 'response' }** on every call, but that is error prone (someone would eventually not add it).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "No way to set global options on HttpClient ( { observe: 'response' } )" (#29732)

Issues.Title: @bazel/bazel always warn that the binary is global
Issues.Body: # üêû bug report ### Affected Package @bazel/bazel ### Is this a regression? Not sure ### Description When using `@bazel/bazel` togather with `@angular/bazel` a warning is being displayed even when the resolved binary is local ``` *** WARNING The Bazel binary is being run from a global install. This means the version may not match the one used in your project. We recommend installing the @bazel/bazel package locally in your project. *** ``` However, taking a look at the binary path it is being resolved to the local one ``` C:\git\cli-repos\my-proj\node_modules\@bazel\bazel\node_modules\@bazel\bazel-win32_x64\package.json ``` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ``` ng new my-proj cd my-proj ng add @angular/bazel ng build ``` ## üî• Exception or Error ``` *** WARNING The Bazel binary is being run from a global install. This means the version may not match the one used in your project. We recommend installing the @bazel/bazel package locally in your project. *** ``` ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** Angular CLI: 8.0.0-beta.11 Node: 10.10.0 OS: win32 x64 Angular: 8.0.0-beta.11 ... animations, bazel, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core ... forms, language-service, platform-browser ... platform-browser-dynamic, router Package Version ----------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.800.0-beta.11 @angular-devkit/build-angular 0.800.0-beta.11 @angular-devkit/build-optimizer 0.800.0-beta.11 @angular-devkit/build-webpack 0.800.0-beta.11 @angular-devkit/core 8.0.0-beta.11 @angular-devkit/schematics 8.0.0-beta.11 @ngtools/webpack 8.0.0-beta.11 @schematics/angular 8.0.0-beta.11 @schematics/update 0.800.0-beta.11 rxjs 6.4.0 typescript 3.3.4000 webpack 4.29.6 **Anything else relevant?** Bazel version 0.24.0 //cc @kyliau,

Issues.Title: fix(forms): type NG_VALUE_ACCESSOR injection token correctly
Issues.Body:
fixes #29351

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?

`NG_VALUE_ACCESSOR` is typed `ControlValueAccessor`. This conflicts with it being used as `multi: true` when injecting it programmatically through `Injector#get` as the function is typed to return a single `ControlValueAccessor`, even though it should be an array of them.

Issue Number: #29351


## What is the new behavior?

The injection token is now typed `ControlValueAccessor[]`.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

I have not added any tests for this as it's purely a type information. This cannot be tested in an assertion kind of test, the only possibility would be a nop `Injector#get` call and making sure the TS compiler doesn't complain. This isn't a functional test, though, and I doubt we generally test that types are correct, so it seems unnecessary.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(forms): type NG_VALUE_ACCESSOR injection token correctly" (#29723)

Issues.Title: next.angular.io/guide/ivy doesn't mention ivy-ngcc
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

https://next.angular.io/guide/ivy comes up if you Google how to enable/disable Ivy in existing project. It states that changing `angularCompilerOptions` is sufficient for that.

However, it doesn't mention the fact that when Angular CLI creates a project with `--experimental-ivy` it adds `postinstall` hook in `package.json` that runs `ivy-ngcc`. It then compiles all dependencies (as far as I understand) for the new compiler. And when you think you've disabled Ivy you are still in fact using it for external libraries, like Angular Material, which seems to be widely incompatible with Ivy.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
### What's the affected URL?**
https://next.angular.io/guide/ivy

### Expected vs Actual Behavior**
Expected: tell about `ivy-ngcc`, what it does and how to fully enable/get rid of Ivy in a project.
Actual: states that changing configuration is enough.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "next.angular.io/guide/ivy doesn't mention ivy-ngcc" (#29719)

Issues.Title: Angular Elements attributes always deserialize to strings
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/elements ### Is this a regression? no ### Description I searched all issues related to angular elements but couldn't find anything else related to that. The problem is that all attributes seem to be deserialized as strings into the property of an Angular Elements. This means that people can't declaratively set a property on an Angular Element if it has any of the following type: - boolean - number - object - array I feel like those attributes should be automatically deserialized to the proper type Furthermore the boolean attributes presence don't follow the HTML specs in the sense that setting a boolean attribute on an angular element like this: ``` ``` will see the `isBeautiful` property be evaluated to false, when it should be true. Setting a value to it (`is-beautiful="true"`) makes it truthy but also a string. This part of the issue is likely related to https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/14761 (but arguably angular elements are talking to the outside world and should follow HTML spec as opposed to angular components) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction stackblitz exposing an element with various attributes types and how setting them impact the value/type of the property of the angular component https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular7-elements-attributes-types?file=src%2Findex.html ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 7.3.7
Node: 10.11.0
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 7.2.11
... common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, elements, forms, http
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                            Version
------------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect          0.10.7
@angular-devkit/build-angular      0.10.7
@angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr   0.13.7
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer    0.10.7
@angular-devkit/build-webpack      0.10.7
@angular-devkit/core               7.0.7

typescript                         3.1.6

**Anything else relevant?** I can see the object and array (complex) types being controversial and arguably not allowing to auto deserialize those, even though it would be a nice feature. However I feel like the boolean and number type should be handled better and not set as `string` by angular when an attribute value changes. What is Angular's position regarding attribute deserialization of angular **elements** in general? Could we get a callback for handling custom deserialization? Should angular at least try to cast "primitive" types (number/boolean)?

Issues.Title: refactor(core): static-query schematic should check templates
Issues.Body:
Queries can technically be also accessed within component templates
e.g.

```html
<my-comp [binding]="myQuery"></my-comp>
```

In that case the query with the property "myQuery" is accessed
statically and needs to be marked with `static: true`. There are
other edge cases that need to be handled as the template property
read doesn't necessarily resolve to the actual query property.

For example:

```html
<foo #myQuery></foo>
<my-comp [binding]="myQuery"></my-comp>
```

In this scenario the binding doesn't refer to the actual query
because the template reference variable takes precedence. The
query doesn't need to be marked with "static: true" this time.

This commit ensures that the `static-query` migration schematic
now handles this cases properly. Also template property reads
that access queries from within a `<ng-template>` are ignored
as these can't access the query before the view has been initialized.

**Note**: Blocked on #29688 

Resolves FW-1216
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(core): static-query schematic should check templates" (#29713)

Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request
Add 3 new commands to speed up and improve QOL for Angular projects and the Angular CLI by introducing ng move, ng rename and ng delete

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
I believe that Angular should have a dedicated set of commands for Moving components, modules and services as well as Renaming and Deleting them right from the CLI.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
I propose the solutions to the three new commands should look like:

ng move [ng mv] currentPathofFolderFile newPathofFolderFile
ng rename [ng rn] oldFolderFileName newFolderFileName
ng delete [ng del] folderFileName

Doing these commands should update the path references for the components/modules/services and of course do the intended action.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
There are a couple VSCode extensions that sort of do this, the most popular being MoveTS but that doesnt update the file paths for angulars needs and ends up making the build fail as it uses the wrong path type.  

Also not everyone who works with Angular uses VSCode as their IDE so they dont have the option for MoveTS like extensions.

Issues.Title: buildOptimizer deleted some code from a property setter in a component that came from an ng-packagr library
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Unknown. ### Description The build optimizer seems to have stripped out some important code. Here's my original TypeScript (template and styles ommitted for brevity): ``` export interface IExpandable { isExpanded: boolean; isExpandedChange: EventEmitter; canExpand: boolean; toggleExpand(): void; expand(); collapse(); } @Component({ selector: 'atlas-expandable-if', template: ` ... `, styles: [` ... `] }) export class ExpandableIfComponent implements IExpandable { @Input() preserveSpaceForIcon: boolean = true; @Input() canExpand: boolean = true; @Input() expandIcon: string; @Input() collapseIcon: string; @Input() loadingIcon: string; @Input() delayedExpand = false; @Input() overrideIcon: string|false = false; @Output() isExpandedChange: EventEmitter = new EventEmitter(); isExpanding = false; constructor(public icons: AtlasIconPaths, private changeDetector: ChangeDetectorRef) { } private _isExpanded = false; get isExpanded(): boolean { return this._isExpanded; } @Input() set isExpanded(value: boolean) { if (this._isExpanded !== value) { this._isExpanded = value; this.isExpandedChange.emit(value); this.changeDetector.markForCheck(); } } clickHeader(event: MouseEvent) { if (!event.shiftKey) { event.preventDefault(); event.stopPropagation(); this.toggleExpand(); } } toggleExpand() { if (this.isExpanding) { return; } if (this.isExpanded || this.canExpand) { if (this.isExpanded) { this.collapse(); } else { this.expand(); } } } expand() { if (this.delayedExpand) { this.isExpanding = true; setTimeout(() => { this.isExpanding = false; this.isExpanded = true; }); this.changeDetector.markForCheck(); } else { this.isExpanded = true; } } collapse() { this.isExpanded = false; } } ``` And here's the code that gets generated with `buildOptimizer: true` (un-minified, but otherwise presented as-is): **Notice the `set isExpanded` property setter** ``` sa = class { constructor(e, t) { this.icons = e, this.changeDetector = t, this.preserveSpaceForIcon = !0, this.canExpand = !0, this.delayedExpand = !1, this.overrideIcon = !1, this.isExpandedChange = new it, this.isExpanding = !1, this._isExpanded = !1 } get isExpanded() { return this._isExpanded } set isExpanded(e) { this._isExpanded !== e && (this._isExpanded = e) } clickHeader(e) { e.shiftKey || (e.preventDefault(), e.stopPropagation(), this.toggleExpand()) } toggleExpand() { this.isExpanding || (this.isExpanded || this.canExpand) && (this.isExpanded ? this.collapse() : this.expand()) } expand() { this.delayedExpand ? (this.isExpanding = !0, setTimeout(() => { this.isExpanding = !1, this.isExpanded = !0 }), this.changeDetector.markForCheck()) : this.isExpanded = !0 } collapse() { this.isExpanded = !1 } }, ``` This code is in a library that gets packaged via `ng-packagr` version 5.0.1. However, here is the code that `ng-packagr` generates: ``` let ExpandableIfComponent = class ExpandableIfComponent { constructor(icons, changeDetector) { this.icons = icons; this.changeDetector = changeDetector; this.preserveSpaceForIcon = true; this.canExpand = true; this.delayedExpand = false; this.overrideIcon = false; this.isExpandedChange = new EventEmitter(); this.isExpanding = false; this._isExpanded = false; } get isExpanded() { return this._isExpanded; } set isExpanded(value) { if (this._isExpanded !== value) { this._isExpanded = value; this.isExpandedChange.emit(value); this.changeDetector.markForCheck(); } } clickHeader(event) { if (!event.shiftKey) { event.preventDefault(); event.stopPropagation(); this.toggleExpand(); } } toggleExpand() { if (this.isExpanding) { return; } if (this.isExpanded || this.canExpand) { if (this.isExpanded) { this.collapse(); } else { this.expand(); } } } expand() { if (this.delayedExpand) { this.isExpanding = true; setTimeout(() => { this.isExpanding = false; this.isExpanded = true; }); this.changeDetector.markForCheck(); } else { this.isExpanded = true; } } collapse() { this.isExpanded = false; } }; __decorate([ Input(), __metadata("design:type", Boolean) ], ExpandableIfComponent.prototype, "preserveSpaceForIcon", void 0); __decorate([ Input(), __metadata("design:type", Boolean) ], ExpandableIfComponent.prototype, "canExpand", void 0); __decorate([ Input(), __metadata("design:type", String) ], ExpandableIfComponent.prototype, "expandIcon", void 0); __decorate([ Input(), __metadata("design:type", String) ], ExpandableIfComponent.prototype, "collapseIcon", void 0); __decorate([ Input(), __metadata("design:type", String) ], ExpandableIfComponent.prototype, "loadingIcon", void 0); __decorate([ Input(), __metadata("design:type", Object) ], ExpandableIfComponent.prototype, "delayedExpand", void 0); __decorate([ Input(), __metadata("design:type", Object) ], ExpandableIfComponent.prototype, "overrideIcon", void 0); __decorate([ Output(), __metadata("design:type", EventEmitter) ], ExpandableIfComponent.prototype, "isExpandedChange", void 0); __decorate([ Input(), __metadata("design:type", Boolean), __metadata("design:paramtypes", [Boolean]) ], ExpandableIfComponent.prototype, "isExpanded", null); ExpandableIfComponent = __decorate([ Component({ selector: 'atlas-expandable-if', template: ` ... styles: [` ... `] }), __metadata("design:paramtypes", [AtlasIconPaths, ChangeDetectorRef]) ], ExpandableIfComponent); ``` The correct code is generated if `buildOptimizer: false` is used in my `angular.json`. ## üåç Your Environment 



Angular CLI: 7.3.7
Node: 11.12.0
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 7.2.11

Issues.Title: style: remove todo comment from `updateClassDeclaration`
Issues.Body:
A transformer should not mutate existing nodes, ever. If you intend to modify some part of the node, the `ts.update*` methods are correct. Or you can replace a node entirely via `ts.create*` operations, but there are cases where introducing entirely synthetic nodes will break TS output.

Hence using the `updateClassDeclaration` in this case is the correct approach.

This has also been raised in the slack #ts-core channel as TypeScript have been looking to get to the bottom of this https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/29365#issuecomment-479230994, which seemed to have been caused by mutating the node.

Also confirmed with @alxhub.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "style: remove todo comment from `updateClassDeclaration`" (#14073)

Issues.Title: Generating module using cli takes long time
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?
Maybe it started taking long time after I installed nativescript for the project.
### Description

Issues.Title: AOT Compilation drops certain functions from Route files silently
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? I am not sure ### Description I am noticing dissonant behavior between AOT compilation and JIT compilation. This in and of itself, is not the concern. The issue is that, in this particular context, AOT and JIT behave similarly but differ without compiler warnings or errors in one particular case. If I define a function on a route's `data` field, it will appear with JIT on `ActivatedRoute.snapshot.firstChild.data`. However, with AOT, it silently drops this field. No compiler error, no compiler warning. This seems to go against the precedent that has been set, wherein both AOT and JIT give compiler errors if you attempt to build with lambda expressions or non exported functions. See example code below. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Serve commands with arguments I used. ``` ng serve -c=debug ng serve -c=debug --aot ``` Example Route ``` { path: 'someroute', component: SomeComponent, pathMatch: 'full', data: { pageTitle: 'Some | Title', doesShowUpWithAOT: doesShowUpWithAOT, // throwsCompileErrorWithAndWithoutAOT: throwsCompileErrorWithAndWithoutAOT, this behaves as expected doesNotShowUpWithAOTAndDoesNotThrowCompilerError() { // behaves inconsistently between JIT and AOT console.log('foo'); }, // alsoThrowsCompilerErrorWithAndWithoutAOT: () => console.log('foo') this behaves as expected } ``` ``` // code from within some class constructor(private _route: ActivatedRoute, private _router: Router) { this._router.events .subcribe(event => { if(event instanceof NavigationEnd) { const data = this._route.snapshot.firstChild.data; const functionMember = data['doesNotShowUpWithAOTAndDoesNotThrowCompilerError']; // is null with AOT, properly defined with JIT } }) } ``` I would argue, for the sake of consistency and explicitness, that both AOT and JIT should throw compiler errors, instead of the function making it through in JIT, and dropping away silently in AOT. I believe this would save development time by cutting down on debugging. Of course, I am always open to an explanation. Thanks! ## üî• Exception or Error 



In this particular case, there is none, which what I contend the bad behavior (bug) is.
## üåç Your Environment OS: Windows 10 Enterprise, 64-bit 



@angular-devkit/architect         0.12.1

Issues.Title: Memory footprint of angular 7
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Unfortunately, I cannot tell precisely, which package of @angular is causing the behavior. ### Is this a regression? Yes, the memory footprint raised a lot after upgrading from angular 6.1.0 to angular 7.1.3. ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... After upgrading a quite large application (about 300-400 components and a lot of providers, @ngxs and @ngrx) from angular+angular/material from v6 to v7 without chaning the rest of the code (only occurences that caused compilation failures) I noticed a lot of memory overhead. Comparing two memory dumps from app before and after upgrade it looks like this: Memory dump of @angular v7 app ![v7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8741982/51113383-1605f080-1802-11e9-84a0-fdad97e3c12e.png) Memory dump of @angular v6 app ![v6](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8741982/51113407-24eca300-1802-11e9-86cb-c567a1bd3afc.png) These heap snapshots were taken after logging in to both apps, navigating to a page with a lot of stuff going on and doing a refresh in both instances. After the initial load finished, I took the snapshots. Comparing the two heap sizes, the heap size difference between v6 and v7 is always the difference of (string) constants in memory. Did anyone notice the same behavior already? Is it something renderer or compiler specific? I don't know, how to isolate the problem. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction As this problem is only notable for a large application, there is no "minimal" repro. I also cannot publish the code of the faulty app, as it is a productive app. ## üî• Exception or Error See Description ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Issues.Title: cdkVirtualFor doesn't render new async emitted items
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
When a new array is emitted from the `BehaviorSubject`, the new items should be rendered in the list.

#### What is the current behavior?
Although new items are emitted from the `BehaviorSubject` in the form of a new array, the items are not rendered. 

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Scrolling down to the bottom of the list causes the `BehaviorSubject` to emit new values. These values are never rendered.
https://stackblitz.com/edit/material-infinite-calendar

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular 7.2.11
Material 7.3.6

#### Is there anything else we should know?
I've posted a SO question here -> https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55369253/cdkvirtualfor-not-rendering-new-items

Because this is a core feature of `cdkVirtualFor`, I'm sure the solution has more to do with the way I'm attempting to _use_ it that there being something wrong with the implementation. That being said, I've been frustrated by this off and on for over a week and I need someone to tell me why it doesn't work the way I think it should.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "cdkVirtualFor doesn't render new async emitted items" (#15736)

Issues.Body:
Handles the constructor breaking changes for 8.0 in `material/button`.

BREAKING CHANGES:
* `_platform` parameter has been removed from the `MatButton` constructor and the `_animationMode` is now required.
* `platform` parameter has been removed from the `MatAnchor` constructor and the `animationMode` is now required.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(button): constructor changes for 8.0" (#15734)

Issues.Title: Inject the RowContext from the CDK Table to a component inside a CdkCell
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
Hi, I really don't know if this is possible, but I would like to define a component inside a CDK table cell that would be able to inject the current row's CdkCellOutletRowContext or the RowContext for that matter. That way the component inside the cell would know its index and element always.

I know that I can declare an input in my component to get that information, but I would like that the component gets that information from the constructor.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?
I don't want to always have to declare an input and pass the input to a component inside one of the CDK table cells, I think it would be better if the component is able to inject that context.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
I don't know if it is technically possible to implement this, or if there is already a solution to this problem.
English is not my first language, please forgive me if I wasn't clear.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Inject the RowContext from the CDK Table to a component inside a CdkCell" (#15733)

Issues.Title: mat-checkbox checkmark SVG issue when using Ivy
Issues.Body:
Checkmark is invisible inside checkbox when using Ivy.
To be precise, SVG element has 0x0 size, doesn't have styles from its class for some reason and Chrome/Firefox don't even allow setting them manually for the element (this is a really peculiar issue).

[Screenshot 1](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mrnateriver/angular-material-checkbox-issue/master/angular_material_checkbox_issue1.png)
[Screenshot 2: Chrome DevTools](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mrnateriver/angular-material-checkbox-issue/master/angular_material_checkbox_issue2.png)

#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
Bug.

#### What is the expected behavior?
Checkmark should be shown.

#### What is the current behavior?
It isn't.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
https://github.com/mrnateriver/angular-material-checkbox-issue
1) `yarn install` or `npm install`;
2) Open `node_modules\@angular\common\fesm5\http.js` and comment out the last line (`export {HttpClientXsrfModule};`) - this fixes [a problem](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/28068) in `ivy-ngcc` in Angular 7.x;
3) Run `ng serve`.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Chrome 73.0.3683.86 and Firefox 66.0.2.
@angular/core 7.2.12
@angular/platform-browser 7.2.12
@angular/material 7.3.7
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-checkbox checkmark SVG issue when using Ivy" (#15727)

Issues.Title: fix(overlay): bounding box calculation with offset
Issues.Body:
When the FlexibleConnectedPositionStrategy tests whether a position fits into the viewport or not, it factors in the provided offsets. However, when the size of the bounding box rect is calculated, the offsets are ignored.
This can lead to too small boxes under the condition that the overlay only fits into the viewport due to its offset. I've setup a [Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-eddfvv) with four examples to demonstrate the issue.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(overlay): bounding box calculation with offset" (#15718)

Issues.Title: Progress bar/spinner animations with NoopAnimationsModule
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
I expect progress bar and spinner animations to still work even when the `NoopAnimationsModule` is imported.

#### What is the current behavior?
Animations are commonly disabled using the `NoopAnimationsModule` in order to gain additional performance especially on mobile devices. Still progress spinners (indeterminate) and bars do not make sense without animation.
As mentioned under the [pull request](https://github.com/angular/material2/pull/10881) which disabled the animations, it might make sense to import the `NoopAnimationsModule` for e2e and screenshot tests. But wouldn't it make sense to rather introduce a hidden switch for that especially for those tests instead of turning off animations completely?

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
> Use `mat-spinner` with NoopAnimationsModule imported.

See [StackBlitz example](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-material2-issue-u1wk46)


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular & Angular Material 7
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Progress bar/spinner animations with NoopAnimationsModule" (#15713)

Issues.Title: Allow drag item inside drop list to be pinned
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
It would be nice if we could pin some drag items inside a list, this way sorting wouldn't have any effect on these elements.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?
If sorting is activated on a list, it does affect all drag items, including disabled ones. We can't prevent a disabled drag item to be sorted too.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow drag item inside drop list to be pinned" (#15712)
